care.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the process of looking after someone, especially because they are ill, old, or very young
care.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: They shared the care of the children.
Care facilities for the elderly are inadequate.
The children had been left in the care of a babysitter.
Mentally ill patients will be under the care of a psychiatrist.
care.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the process of doing things to keep something in good condition and working correctly
care.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: With proper care, the washing machine should last for years.
care.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: when you are careful to avoid damage, mistakes etc
care.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The note on the box said ‘Fragile – handle with care’.
The picture had been drawn with great care.
care.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: something that causes problems and makes you anxious or sad
care.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: At last I felt free from my cares.
Alex looked as though he didn’t have a care in the world (=had no problems or worries).
a man with the cares of the world on his shoulders (=with a lot of problems or worries)
care.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: People expect good standards of medical care.
The government has put a lot more money into health care.
£50.6m is to be spent on hospital care.
Most mentally ill people are now treated through community care.
You can find home care through family service agencies.
The changes should lead to better patient care.
Outpatient care is generally less expensive than a stay in hospital.
The important thing is the quality of the nursing care.
They used the money to pay for residential care.
He needed intensive care for several weeks.
Children with both parents working long hours need after-school care.
The home provides short-term care for elderly people.
The charity provides care and shelter for homeless people.
She had an aging mother who required constant care.
Every citizen has the right to receive health care.
She's a part-time care worker with mentally ill adults.
How much money is spent on health care services?
care.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: carefulness
care
if you do something with care, you are careful to avoid damage, mistakes etc
She put the needle in with great care.
Everyone should take care in the sun.
caution
care to avoid danger or risks, or care about trusting information that might not be true
Her evidence should be treated with caution.
There was a certain lack of caution among investors.
prudence
a sensible and careful attitude that makes you avoid unnecessary risks – a rather formal use
Banks should show more prudence in lending money.
vigilance
careful attention to what is happening, so that you will notice any danger or illegal activity
Governments from across the world have called for greater vigilance against Internet-based crime.
There is a need for constant vigilance to protect vulnerable people.
regard for something
careful attention and consideration shown to something, to avoid danger or risks – used especially when someone fails to do this
The court heard that the company had shown no regard for the safety of its employees.
These men are cold-blooded killers and have little regard for human life.
tact
care not to say anything that might offend or upset someone
He handled the matter with a great deal of tact.
discretion
care to deal with situations in a way that does not embarrass, upset or offend people, especially by not telling any of their secrets
Any confidential information was treated with discretion.
care.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to think that something is important, so that you are interested in it, worried about it etc
care.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The only thing he seems to care about is money.
She didn’t care what her father thought.
care.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to be concerned about what happens to someone, because you like or love them
care.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: I care about him and hate to see him hurt like this.
care.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: take care of somebody
to make sure a child or an old or sick person is safe and has the things they need
I have to look after my little brother.
Taking care of a baby is hard work.
She is taking care of her grandmother while her grandfather is in hospital.
care for somebody
to take care of someone. Care for somebody is less common and more formal than take care of/look after somebody
He was cared for by a team of nurses.
Caring for an elderly relative can be very rewarding.
nurse
to look after someone who is ill
He nursed his wife through a long illness.
The monks nursed him back to health (=looked after him until he was well again).
babysit
to look after children in the evening while their parents go out somewhere
I’ll ask Jane to babysit on Wednesday night.
He used to babysit for Mary when she worked nights.
mind
to look after a child while their parents are not there, especially for a short time
Will you mind the baby while I go to the shop?
care.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: (Cooperative for American Relief to Everywhere) an organization that sends special boxes of food, clothing, and medicine called ‘CARE packages’ to places in the world where they are needed. The organization started in the US but now includes 12 member countries.
